inference:
Since $\overline{PN}$ and $\overline{GA}$ are diameters, $\angle PNA = 90^\circ$ and $\angle GPA = 90^\circ$.
$\angle GOP = 78^\circ$.
In quadrilateral $PNAG$, the sum of the angles is $360^\circ$.
$\angle PNA + \angle GPA + \angle NGA + \angle GPN = 360^\circ$.
$90^\circ + 90^\circ + \angle NGA + \angle GPN = 360^\circ$.
$180^\circ + \angle NGA + \angle GPN = 360^\circ$.
$\angle NGA + \angle GPN = 180^\circ$.
Since $\overline{PN}$ is a diameter, $\angle PGN$ and $\angle GPN$ are inscribed angles subtending the same arc, so $\angle GPN$ intercepts arc $GN$.
$\angle GOP = 78^\circ$, which is the central angle subtending arc $GP$.
Thus, $\overset{\Large\frown}{GP} = 78^\circ$.
Since $\overline{PN}$ is a diameter, $\overset{\Large\frown}{PN} = 180^\circ$.
$\overset{\Large\frown}{GN} = \overset{\Large\frown}{PN} - \overset{\Large\frown}{GP} - \overset{\Large\frown}{PN} - \overset{\Large\frown}{NP} = 180^\circ - 78^\circ = 102^\circ$.
So $\angle GPN = \frac{1}{2}\overset{\Large\frown}{GN} = \frac{1}{2}(102^\circ) = 51^\circ$.
Then, $\angle NGA + \angle GPN = 180^\circ$,
$\angle NGA + 51^\circ = 180^\circ$.
$\angle NGA = 180^\circ - 51^\circ = 129^\circ$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{129}$
ground_truth: Since $\overline{GA}$ and $\overline{PN}$ are diameters, point $O$ is the center of the circle.  We have $\angle AON = \angle GOP = 78^\circ$, so arc $AN$ has measure $78^\circ$.  Since $\angle NGA$ is inscribed in arc $AN$, we have $\angle NGA = \frac12\cdot 78^\circ = \boxed{39^\circ}$.

inference:
Given that $\overline{PN}$ and $\overline{GA}$ are diameters, $\angle PNA = 90^\circ$ and $\angle GPA = 90^\circ$.
$\angle GOP = 78^\circ$.
Quadrilateral $PNAG$ has $\angle PNA + \angle GPA + \angle NGA + \angle GPN = 360^\circ$.
$90^\circ + 90^\circ + \angle NGA + \angle GPN = 360^\circ$.
$180^\circ + \angle NGA + \angle GPN = 360^\circ$.
$\angle NGA + \angle GPN = 180^\circ$.

Since $\overline{PN}$ is a diameter, $\angle PGN$ and $\angle GPN$ intercept the same arc $\overset{\Large\frown}{GN}$. The central angle $\angle GOP$ intercepts arc $\overset{\Large\frown}{GP} = 78^\circ$. The angle subtended by diameter $\overline{PN}$ is $180^\circ$, so arc $\overset{\Large\frown}{PN} = 180^\circ$.
Then arc $\overset{\Large\frown}{GN} = \overset{\Large\frown}{PN} - \overset{\Large\frown}{GP} = 180^\circ - 78^\circ = 102^\circ$.

The inscribed angle $\angle GPN$ intercepts arc $\overset{\Large\frown}{GN}$.
$\angle GPN = \frac{1}{2} \overset{\Large\frown}{GN} = \frac{1}{2} (102^\circ) = 51^\circ$.

$\angle NGA + \angle GPN = 180^\circ$
$\angle NGA + 51^\circ = 180^\circ$.
$\angle NGA = 180^\circ - 51^\circ = 129^\circ$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{129}$
ground_truth: Since $\overline{GA}$ and $\overline{PN}$ are diameters, point $O$ is the center of the circle.  We have $\angle AON = \angle GOP = 78^\circ$, so arc $AN$ has measure $78^\circ$.  Since $\angle NGA$ is inscribed in arc $AN$, we have $\angle NGA = \frac12\cdot 78^\circ = \boxed{39^\circ}$.
